In a similar vein, I noticed that the physical model
is not accurate, because the final "good" walker has
it's feet well to the right & left of the center of
gravity, and yet there is no side-to-side wobble. 
Furthermore the motion of each leg appears to be
planar.  Two legs each doing planar motion in
different planes will not be stable in the real world;
it will wobble from side to side with increasing
amplitude.  I think the demo is "rigged".

--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> I wanted to add: After looking closely at
> "Generation 0" in that 
> clip, it's pretty clear there is some kind of
> constraint.  Even this 
> flailing body on the ground is alternating its legs,
> albeit in an 
> unproductive way.  But how can that alternation be
> present at 
> generation 0?  Obviously they somehow forced it that
> way.  I think 
> it's pretty exciting because I doubt they have the
> same quality 
> neuroevolution technology as NEAT, which suggests
> that the problem 
> actually isn't that hard given the right
> constraints, which implies 
> Tyler could possibly evolve even more sophisticated
> behaviors than 
> these guys have.  
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley"
> <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> > Wow, that's pretty nice!  Did you see the demo of
> their evolution:
> > 
> >
>
http://www.naturalmotion.com/pages/technology_hiw.htm
> > 
> > It's very strange that it's walking well after
> only 20 
> generations.

> it 
> > does show this pursuit is feasible.  But it
> clearly needs the 
> right

> constraints.  For 
> > example, maybe it must be impossible for it to

> > forward at the same time?
> >
